docs.lead_paragraph: Aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer, the Democratic governor of New York, are saying this morning that he is likely to resign today in the face of the widening scandal over his role as a client of a high-end prostitution ring. As of Tuesday night, Mr. Spitzer had continued to be sealed up in his Fifth Avenue home with his family and top aides, debating whether to resign or -- as some aides say his wife was advocating -- to try to stay in office and fight on, as Danny Hakim and Ian Urbina reported. Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson would be sworn in as New York's governor in Albany on Monday, when the resignation takes effect, an aide to the governor said.

headline.main: Spitzer to Resign Today, Aides Say

docs.abstract: An overview of the coverage of the Spitzer scandal, in The Times and other newspapers.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (A&E) GENE SIMMONS FAMILY JEWELS A cosmetically refreshed Gene Simmons (above with, from left, his daughter, Sophie; his partner, Shannon Tweed; and his son, Nick) returns for a third season of rock 'n' roll meets family man reality. First: a lie detector test to find out whether Mr. Simmons, the Kiss frontman whose tongue is a legend in its own right, met the 4,800 women he claims to have been with before 1983, the year he committed to Ms. Tweed, a former Playboy centerfold. 8 P.M. (CW) BEAUTY AND THE GEEK In this fifth-season premiere, nine women and nine men learn that they'll be competing as two teams, the beauties against the geeks, instead of beauty-geek pairs. For the first challenge, the beauties are made to look unattractive and then must try to get phone numbers from men in a bar. The geeks are sent to a quiz room, after which one is sent home.

docs.lead_paragraph: The film, an eight-part documentary and the first by Sharon Liese, a single mother and corporate marketer, tracks 12 teenage girls through four demanding, withering years at a public school outside Kansas City.
